rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Electrolytic iron : a study of the production of iron by electrolysis, with special reference to its recovery from sulphide ores
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Iron, is the oommonest, most widely used, and at the same time the most vitally important of all the base metals. In the growth and developement of modern civilization it assumes a dominant position.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Metallurgy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Imperial Federation Movement with special reference to Canada
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: At the present day there are three possible destinies for Canada: to remain in the Empire; to become annexed to the United States; or to become independent. These three may be traced back to the time when Canada became a British Colony, even before the American Revolution. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: History

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The satirical aspect of Thackeray’s work
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Thackeray has been accused of being a cynic. It was about the time that Vanity Fair was making its appearance, when its author was wishing with all his heart that he could produce a book which would appeal to the public like those of Dickens, that the charge began to gain ground. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The kerogen in pyrobituminous shale
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Kerogen is the name given to the organic matter which occurs in coal and pyrobituminous shale. The correct adjective to describe a kerogen-containing shale is "pyrobituminous", which indicates that it gives an oil on pyrolysis or destructive distillation, - its most important property commercially. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Radiotherapeutic measurements
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The application of X-ray photography to medical diagnosis, and the widespread use of violet rays, X-rays, and Radium rays inthe treatment of certain diseases make the accurate gauging of the Various "dosages" administered essential, the possible consequences of an overdose being very serious. It is necessary either to be able to measure the intensity and character of the radiation at the point desired in standard units, or to repeat exactly a dose which experience has shown to be safe and effdctive. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A portrayal of the clergyman in the fiction of Jane Austen, Mrs. Gaskell, the Bronte sisters, and George Eliot
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In studying the characters of clergymen pictured in the field outlined by the subject of this thesis, we are touching a very interesting subject, for, by turning our minds in this direction we may see in what light was viewed a profession which has always held an important position in the history of the English people. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Memoirs of the stage
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In my study of "Memoirs of the Stage", I have used the title in its widest sense to include, in addition to autobiography and personal record, diaries, letters, reminiscences and biographies of men and women connected with the stage, either professionally as actors or as critics of dramatic art, or simply as interested and intelligent playgoers. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Du travail en la Nouvelle France
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: La résultante des forces sociales qui s'appliquèrent à l'exploitation de l'Amérique du Nord dépassait toutefois en grandeur et en intensité la puissance qui adapta au besoin de l'homme la nature libre de l'ancien continent. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Observations relative to the constitution of caoutchouc
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The constitution of caoutchouc is a problem which has interested and baffled organic chemists ever since the work of Williams in 1860. This investigator discovered that the pyrogenic decomposition of caoutchouc yielded as one of the chief products, isoprene. Later in the same year he noticed that the isoprene fraction obtained from rubber, on standing for a period of months, was transformed into a viscous fluid. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some derivatives of the diquinolines
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Until comparatively recently the difficulties in the way of establishing formulae for these bodies appeared almost insuperable, owing to the complexity of their molecules and the apparent want of connection between their chemical behaviour and that of the well studied groups of organic substances. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An investigation of the specific heats and latent heats of fusion at low temperatures
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The discussion and experimental work given int the following pages are, to a large extent, preliminary to that for the Ph.D. thesis. The latter will deal with "Heat Changes in the Neighbourhood of the Critical Temperature". This will involve the determination of the specific heats of compressed gases and liquids in the neighbourhood of the critical temperature, to see whether there are energy changes at this point which would correspond to the discontinuities in the usual PV-P curves above the critical temperature. This work, it is hoped, will also lead to theoritical deductions of the specific heats of liquids, as the continual and gradual change from gas to liquid will be followed by specific heat measurements.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Jurisdiction in matrimonial causes in the Dominion of Canada
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is the object of this thesis to present the law of matrimonial causes in its international aspect, as it is administered by the courts of the Dominion of Canada. Private international law as a branch of the whole body of law has been ably and exhaustively dealt with by jurists; the law of marriage and divorce and the domestic relations has been equally well expounded; but there has as yet been no published work on the international law of matrimonial causes as it is particularly applied to Canada. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Law

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The differential flotation of a complex head ore by the use of a single-cell, laboratory type apparatus for intermittant mechanical agitation; and a comparison of these results with those obtained with an 8-cell continuous agitation machine
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In some cases of ores amenable to Flotation it has become an economic question to decide whether to use flotation or gravity means of concentration, while in others, although not a panacea, flotation has resulted in a tremendous saving of mineral in the finer sizes where ordinary means of separation by gravity processes failed. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ore Dressing

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The three phases of Nietzsche’s philosophy
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: There are few men in the history of modern thought who have been so much known and yet so little understood as Frederick Nietzche. He has been quoted, by both friends and enemies, in many countries, on both sides of the Atlantic. Much has been put into his words, by both ardent friends and bitter opponents that Nietzche never meant. In fact, something very extraordinary happened in his case: his most devoted disciples have, in their zeal for the propagation of their master's teaching distorted the face of their master's teaching as greatly as have his enemies. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Philosophy
Nietzsche, Friedrich Wilhelm, 1844-1900

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Mechanism of vulcanisation cataly
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Goodyear was the first to employ a catalyst in heating rubber and sulphur together, thus originating the process known as vulcanisation. This catalyst was an inorganic lead compound; and inorganic catalysts, especially compounds of lead, magnesium and calcium, have been in general use in the rubber industry since Goodyear's discovery. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry
Rubber
Vulcanization

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Dykes encountered in Mount Royal tunnel between stations 183+35 and 195+61
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This paper contains a description of the dykes encountered in a section of the Canadian National Railway tunnel through Mount Royal. The section is 1226 feet in length from station 188+35 in Trenton limestone, 3492 feet west of the eastern portal of the tunnel, to station 195+61 within the essexite, 91 feet beyond its contact with the limestone. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The comparative effect of several systems of fertilizing on crop production and soil fertility
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: One of the most important progressive steps taken in agriculture was made when it was first concluded that greater returns came from rotating crops on the land instead of growing these crops continuously on the same land. From earliest times it has been known that the application of chalk, certain calcareous muds, refuse from the barn and so forth increased the returns from the land. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agronomy
Fertilizers

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Phosphate deficiency in Quebec soils
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Agriculture in our Province suffers at present from a very alarming economic crisis. On all sides, men have been studying the causes of the desertion of our farms and remedies for it. The cause is always the same: "Agriculture does not pay." And the remedy is to make agriculture more remunerative. The principles which underlie the fertility of the soils have been slowly but surely discovered by the capable cooperation of technicians and experimenters. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The education of the Jewish child in the light of Mishnaic and Talmudic law
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The secret of the persistence of the Jewish people lies in the fact that throughout their history they have never allowed themselves to sever a single link in the continuity of their history. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Oriental Languages

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The geology of the Outsider Mine, Maple Bay, Portland Canal, B.C.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the summer of 1921 the Granby Consolidated Mining and Smelting Co., acting on the advice of Dr. J.A.Bancroft took an option on the property. Since then development work, performed on the basis of geological information gathered, has revealed ore reserves very considerably in excess of those previously known. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: On the effects of anaesthetics on body temperature and blood solids at various environmental temperatures
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The main object of carrying out the investigations about to be described was to ascertain whether some of the deviations from normal physiological conditions seen in anaesthesia might not be influenced by changes in environmental conditions. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the oldest dykes of Mount Royal : bostonites, tinguaites etc., and their altered equivalents
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The present paper deals with the oldest dykes. that were encountered in the Mount Royal tunnel. A brief comparative study is also made of a sheet of bostonite of the same age from Moffat Island which is situated in the St. Lawrence River a short distance north of the eastern portion of Victoria Bridge. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geology & Mineralogy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Methods of checking and competition in relation to comparative crop tests
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In recent years, agronomists have devoted considerable attention to the question of experimental methods, and a great deal of investigational work dealing with this problem has already been done. These investigations show that field tests, as ordinarily conducted, are subject to large errors from different sources. One source of error is the variation of soil productivity due to differences in composition, fertility, and other factors. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Field experiments
Field crops
Agronomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Pentosan content in relation to winter hardiness in commercial varieties of the apple
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: There are many parts of Canada in which the apple is not, and cannot be, at present grown. This is particularly true of that section of the country extending from the Great Lakes to the Rocky Mountains, or the whole of the central plains region.Throughout this entire district the production of apples is restricted to that of a very few hardy varieties of Russian origin, and to crabs, because of the impossibility of growing standard varieties owing to their susceptibility to winter killing. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The transportation of Canadian wheat to the sea
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The cultivation of the soil in Canada dates back to the earliest known times. When Cartier sailed up the St. Lawrence in 1535 he found that the Indians were already growing corn in cultivated patches around Hochelaga. With the white man came the cultivation of wheat, a plant unknown on the North American Continent, for the first crop ever grown ini Canada was raised there in the same year. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics & Political Science
